title: Exploring with Sora.
text:
Recently, I have been getting a lot of AI generated videos on my for you page. After further investgiation I realized that they were made with Open AI’s Sora. Sora is a model that can generate full-on videos from text prompts that is said to be capable of rendering actual scenes with motion, lighting, and camera movement. I wanted to see if Sora could live up to the hype. Could it not only interpret a prompt creatively, but visually deliver on that idea in a coherent way?
So I ran two tests:
Prompting Sora to generate a short, surreal video
Prompting it to create a cinematic-style clip with specific visual details and motion
I will upload the results of both tests below. Given the format of the document, I will include an image of the video and a description of what happens since I can’t embed videos.


Prompt I submitted: “Generate a video of a fluffy white cat made of clouds walking across giant piano keys suspended in the sky. The scene is dreamlike and uses soft lighting. The camera slowly tracks the cat from behind.”*
What Sora produced:

The output matched the prompt fairly closely. It showed a white, cloud-like cat walking forward across oversized piano keys that stretch into the clouds. The background was a soft, bright sky with puffy clouds in the distance. The cat didn’t do much beyond walking forward — it moved a little clumsily but stayed upright. The video resembled the image above, just with the cat shifting slightly and moving one step at a time. The camera followed from behind at a steady pace, and the lighting stayed soft and consistent throughout.
Analysis: This video felt more like a simple animated loop than a cinematic scene, but it delivered on what was asked. The cat had a light, fluffy texture that matched the “cloud” description, and the piano keys were rendered at scale with clean lines and consistent shading. The surreal quality came more from the concept than the execution — nothing wild or glitchy happened, and the cat just kept walking. The realism wasn’t photorealistic, but the visuals were clear and coherent. Overall, it showed that Sora can handle light creative prompts like this with solid output, even if the result is more like a moving concept sketch than a polished short film.



Prompt I submitted: “Create realistic drone footage of Tokyo at night. Show tall buildings, neon signs in Japanese, light reflections on wet streets, and cars moving through intersections. The camera should move smoothly between buildings like a drone fly-through.”*
What Sora generated:

The output was a short video clip nearly identical to the image above — a quiet Tokyo street at night, viewed from above. Neon signs in Japanese lit up both sides of the street, casting reflections onto the wet pavement. The buildings were tall and dimly lit with interior office lights. Cars moved slowly through the scene, and the drone-style camera stayed steady as it tracked forward. The lighting was soft but detailed, capturing the subtle glows and reflections you’d expect from a rainy night in the city.
Analysis: Sora handled this prompt well. The video wasn’t overly stylized or cinematic — it felt more like a calm, slightly moody cityscape. The buildings, signage, and lighting all looked accurate and proportional, and the reflections on the street were consistent with the wet ground. The cars moving through the intersection were smooth and natural. While the signs themselves weren’t animated, the overall realism of the scene, especially in terms of light, motion, and composition, showed that Sora can produce convincing short clips with minimal surrealism. It worked especially well for this kind of urban, ambient content.

title: Can Chat GPT beat itself?
text: Chat GPT has a feature where it has multiple “Custom GPTs” on its site; these include “Code Copilot,”Sora”, and today’s star “AI Humanizer.” I will initially feed it an outline for my Op-Ed from my freshman year writing seminar and tell it to write an Op-ed using it. Then I am going to run it through GPT 0 and see the AI result. After that, I will put it through “AI Humanizer” and other GPT humanizer bots to see if it can lower the overall AI score or even get through the detector altogether.

title: Can Chat GPT beat itself?
text:
Updated AI Score
96% AI generated 4% Mixed 0% Human
Suprisingly, the Humanizer GPT returned a higher AI score then before and didn’t create any text that GPTo could register as human. Since the custom GPTs are failing to return better results than the base GPT model, I will try to experiment more with the base model.
I Prompted it with the following:
“This returned an AI score of 78% AI-generated 1% Mixed 21% Human
Could you humanize it more.”
“Let’s Stop Letting Algorithms Decide Who Gets Policed By Ethan Roytman
Imagine being flagged as a potential criminal—not because of something you did, but because of where you live or how often police have historically shown up in your neighborhood. That’s the reality for too many people living in cities across the U.S., thanks to a growing reliance on predictive policing.
At first glance, predictive policing sounds like a smart use of technology. Feed crime data into a computer, let it find patterns, and use those patterns to stop crimes before they happen. Sounds efficient, right?
But here’s the problem: the data being used isn’t neutral. It reflects decades of over-policing in predominantly Black, Latino, and low-income neighborhoods. So when these algorithms predict where police should go next, they usually point right back to the same communities that have been under surveillance for years. It’s not a smarter system—it’s a loop. And the people caught in it are often the ones already struggling under the weight of systemic inequality.
Take a neighborhood with a long history of police presence. Maybe crime gets reported more often there—not because people are committing more crimes, but because police are constantly around, stopping people, writing things up. The algorithm picks up on this and flags the area as “high risk,” leading to even more patrols. It becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.
Meanwhile, we’re not solving anything. Predictive policing doesn’t ask why crime happens. It doesn’t deal with poverty, joblessness, poor education, or the lack of mental health care. It doesn’t offer hope, opportunity, or safety in any meaningful sense. It just sends more officers into places already stretched thin, while ignoring the deeper reasons people turn to crime in the first place.
Some people argue these algorithms help make police work more effective. That they spot patterns officers might miss. That they save time, resources, and money. But if the patterns are built on flawed data, what are we really improving? Efficiency isn’t a virtue if it’s just making inequality faster.
We’ve reached a point where it’s not enough to ask whether technology works—we have to ask what kind of society it’s helping us build. And right now, predictive policing is pushing us further away from justice, not closer to it.
Ending the use of these algorithms doesn’t mean giving up on public safety. It means rethinking what real safety looks like. It means investing in schools, after-school programs, community centers, jobs. It means understanding that safety isn’t just about stopping bad things from happening—it’s about making good things possible in the first place.
Algorithms don’t have to be villains. But they’re only as fair as the data we feed them—and our criminal justice data is full of bias. Until we fix that, we shouldn’t be using machines to make decisions that affect real people’s lives.
We have the chance to break the cycle. Let’s stop relying on predictive policing and start investing in what truly keeps communities safe.”

title: Can Chat GPT beat itself?
text:
AI Score
84% AI generated 0% Mixed 16% Human
Again, asking for a more humanized version somehow led to a higher AI score. This could imply either a) GPT0 is relatively inaccurate and has a high margin error or b) GPT is relatively ineffective at humanizing and goes in circles.

title: A Deep Dive into Deep Research
text: This post will be somewhat unconventional. The nature of deep research is that it takes 5-15 minutes to do a deep dive into the internet and generates around 5000 words of analysis. I prompted Chat GPT 4.5 and Deep Research to create an analysis of Trump’s first 50 days in office focused on policy changes, executive orders, and socio-economic impact.

title: A Deep Dive into Deep Research
section: First 50 Days of Trump’s 2025 Presidency: Policy Shifts, Executive Orders, and Impact
text:
First 50 Days of Trump’s 2025 Presidency: Policy Shifts, Executive Orders, and Impact
In his first 50 days back in office (January 20 – March 10, 2025), President Donald Trump pursued a whirlwind of policy changes and executive actions. These moves spanned domestic and foreign affairs and were accompanied by immediate economic and social reactions. Below is an in-depth analysis of this period, organized into policy changes, key executive orders, and socio-economic impacts.

title: A Deep Dive into Deep Research
text:
Policy Changes

Domestic Policy Shifts
Trump rapidly reversed many of his predecessor’s domestic policies and introduced new initiatives reflecting his 2016–2020 agenda. Immigration enforcement tightened significantly. On Day 1, Trump signed orders to “Secure Our Borders” and “Protect the American People Against Invasion,” reinstating strict border controls and nullifying several of President Biden’s 2021 immigration directives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). These actions restarted border wall construction and imposed tougher asylum and deportation rules, prompting legal challenges by immigrant advocacy groups. Trump also moved to realign the U.S. refugee program, slashing refugee admissions and revoking Biden’s earlier refugee order (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders).
Economic and regulatory policy took a sharp turn. The administration imposed a regulatory freeze and launched a “Department of Government Efficiency” initiative to shrink the federal bureaucracy (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). A hiring near-freeze was implemented alongside plans to cut tens of thousands of federal jobs (e.g. a leaked memo outlined 80,000 layoffs at the VA alone) (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). High-profile business advisor Elon Musk was tasked to lead the efficiency drive, even appearing with Trump in Congress as head of the new initiative (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Trump’s team also signaled intent to abolish the Department of Education, with a draft executive order directing the Education Secretary to plan the department’s closure (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). In tandem, Trump issued orders to “End Radical Indoctrination” in schools and promote “patriotic education,” targeting diversity curricula and COVID-related school policies (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). These moves pleased conservative constituencies but alarmed educators and civil rights groups.
The administration swiftly dismantled diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programs across the government. One early order revoked dozens of prior executive orders dating back to the 1960s that had mandated affirmative action and diversity initiatives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Trump framed these reversals as “restoring merit-based opportunity,” effectively ending affirmative action requirements for federal contractors and agencies. He also ordered the elimination of federal “DEI” training and offices as “illegal and immoral discrimination programs” (Executive Order: Ending Radical And Wasteful Government DEI …). Additionally, Trump enforced a strict interpretation of gender and reproductive policies: he banned transgender women from women’s sports via executive order (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), directed federal agencies to recognize only biological sex in policy (“restoring biological truth”) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), and moved to enforce the Hyde Amendment by barring federal funds for abortion-related services (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Each of these actions was met with praise from social conservatives and protests from LGBTQ and women’s rights advocates.
Trump’s energy and environmental policy reversed course from the prior administration. He declared a “National Energy Emergency” on Day 1 to boost fossil fuel production (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) and signed an expansive “Unleashing American Energy” order that revoked a host of Biden-era climate initiatives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). This order opened federal lands and offshore areas to oil and gas drilling, rolled back emissions regulations, and scrapped considerations of climate change in agency decisions (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). The administration also greenlit projects like the Keystone XL pipeline and Arctic oil development (“Unleashing Alaska’s Resource Potential”) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Fossil fuel industries and allied lawmakers applauded these steps, while environmental groups decried the U.S. exit from international climate efforts (the Day 1 order “Putting America First in International Environmental Agreements” signaled withdrawal from the Paris Accord commitments) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders).
Law and order policies were another focus. Trump moved to reinstate federal executions, ending a de facto moratorium on the death penalty (“Restoring the Death Penalty”) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). He championed gun rights with an order “Protecting Second Amendment Rights” that rolled back federal gun-control efforts (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). In addition, he established a White House faith-based office and ordered federal agencies to combat “anti-Christian bias,” signaling support for religious conservatives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Each of these policy shifts set a new direction for federal agencies and often directly countermanded Biden administration priorities.


Foreign Policy Shifts
Trump’s early foreign policy moves reflected an “America First” approach marked by retrenchment from global institutions and confrontational trade measures. Immediately upon taking office, he withdrew the United States from the World Health Organization (WHO) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), reversing the prior re-entry and cutting off U.S. funding to WHO. He also issued an order to “withdraw from and review support for certain United Nations organizations”, putting U.N.-affiliated agencies on notice and halting funds to groups like the National Endowment for Democracy (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Allies and international observers expressed concern at these steps, warning of diminished U.S. influence in global health and democracy promotion.
Trump quickly upended U.S. trade policy. In late January and early February, he signed a series of orders imposing new tariffs and duties: targeting China’s supply of fentanyl-related chemicals, he levied a tariff on Chinese goods to pressure Beijing (“Imposing Duties to Address the Synthetic Opioid Supply Chain in China”) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders); to compel Mexico to curb illegal migration, he announced tariffs on Mexican exports (“Duties to Address the Situation at Our Southern Border”) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders); and he placed duties on Canadian imports citing cross-border drug flows (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). By early March, this escalated into a full-fledged trade war, as Trump hiked tariffs on China to 20% and slapped a new 25% duty on most Canadian and Mexican imports (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). He partially walked back some tariffs (granting a short-term exemption for goods under the USMCA rules of origin) amid frantic negotiations (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Nonetheless, these actions marked “the end of the zero-tariff era,” as Trump declared, and signaled a return to protectionism (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). U.S. farmers, in particular, were warned to “bear with” the short-term pain of lost export markets, as Trump acknowledged an adjustment period ahead (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Indeed, European and other trading partners retaliated with tariffs of their own by March (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters), straining relations with traditional allies.
Beyond trade, Trump pursued an aggressive stance on national security. He re-designated the Yemeni rebel group Ansar Allah (the Houthis) as a Foreign Terrorist Organization (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), reversing a Biden-era policy to delist them, despite humanitarian concerns in Yemen. He also sanctioned the International Criminal Court (ICC) and its officials (“Imposing Sanctions on the ICC”), reviving a dispute over ICC probes of U.S. personnel (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). In the Middle East, Trump strengthened ties with Israel’s security establishment – for example, announcing an “Iron Dome for America” program to develop U.S. missile defenses modeled on Israel’s system (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). At the same time, he took a hard line against groups viewed as threats: a Day 1 order directed the government to treat foreign drug cartels akin to terrorist organizations, facilitating tougher action against them (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). He also signaled a more combative posture toward adversaries in cyberspace and technology, ordering a review to ban or restrict apps like TikTok that are controlled by foreign rivals (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders).
Overall, Trump’s first 50 days saw a dramatic reorientation of U.S. policy. Domestically, his administration veered sharply right on immigration, social issues, and deregulation, while internationally it embraced unilateralism and economic nationalism. Many changes were enacted unilaterally via executive fiat, setting the stage for legal battles and political clashes in the months ahead.

title: A Deep Dive into Deep Research
section: Executive Orders: Key Actions and Consequences
text:
Executive Orders: Key Actions and Consequences
President Trump heavily relied on executive orders (EOs) to enact his agenda swiftly. By March 13, he had signed 82 EOs in his first 50 days, an unprecedented pace (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). (For comparison, this nearly matched the total number of EOs in his entire first term.) He issued 26 EOs on Inauguration Day alone (Executive Order: Securing Our Borders (Donald Trump, 2025)). These orders targeted a wide range of policies. Below are some of the most significant EOs from this period, along with their intent and immediate effects:

“Initial Rescissions of Harmful EOs and Actions” (EO 14148, Jan 20, 2025): This sweeping Day 1 order nullified many of President Biden’s executive orders on climate, equity, immigration, and more (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It revoked at least 17 orders signed in 2021 (including orders on racial equity, climate regulations, and immigration) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Intent: Erase the prior administration’s policy legacy in one stroke. Immediate consequence: Dozens of federal initiatives (from rejoining the Paris Climate Accord to DEI programs in agencies) were halted or reversed overnight, prompting confusion within agencies and celebratory statements from Trump allies who opposed those initiatives.
“Securing Our Borders” (EO 14165, Jan 20, 2025): One of several immigration orders signed immediately, it directed the construction of new border barriers and deployment of resources to the southern border (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It also ended the practice of catch-and-release and reinstated Trump-era asylum restrictions that Biden had rolled back. Intent: Fulfill campaign promises to crack down on illegal immigration and “finish the wall.” Consequences: Within days, contractors were notified to resume border wall projects, and border patrol began operating under tougher rules. Immigration advocacy groups filed lawsuits, and by mid-February, federal courts were reviewing challenges to these policies on humanitarian and legal grounds (e.g., questioning the reinstated asylum limits).
“Protecting the United States From Foreign Terrorists” (EO 14161, Jan 20, 2025): This order effectively reimposed a travel ban by suspending entry of individuals from several countries deemed high-risk for terrorism (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It expanded on Trump’s 2017 travel ban, adding new vetting measures. Intent: Prevent terrorist infiltration by tightening visa issuance and entry from certain Middle Eastern and African nations. Immediate consequence: Travel from the affected countries was abruptly halted, stranding some travelers and drawing protest from civil liberties groups. The order faced immediate court challenges, recalling the legal battles from 2017.
“Unleashing American Energy” (EO 14154, Jan 20, 2025): A comprehensive energy order that rolled back environmental regulations and prioritized fossil fuel development (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It revoked numerous climate-related orders (11 of Biden’s climate EOs were listed for revocation) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) and instructed agencies to expedite permits for oil, gas, and coal projects. Intent: Promote energy independence and economic growth by removing “burdensome” green regulations. Consequences: The Department of Interior promptly restarted oil lease sales on federal land, and the EPA moved to loosen emissions standards. Oil and gas companies’ stock prices rose on anticipation of friendlier policy, while environmental organizations mobilized opposition, with some states preparing lawsuits citing environmental harm.
“Department of Government Efficiency” Initiative (EO 14158, Jan 20, 2025): This order created a new cross-agency task force (dubbed the Department of Government Efficiency, or “DOGE”) to cut federal jobs, slash regulations, and reorganize agencies (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Elon Musk was appointed as an adviser to this effort, reflecting Trump’s outsourcing of innovation to private-sector figures (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Intent: Radically shrink the federal bureaucracy and reduce government spending. Immediate consequence: Agencies instituted near-freezes on hiring and began identifying programs for cuts. Federal employee unions reacted with outrage – by early March, union-led protests at state capitols and in D.C. drew thousands, decrying “illegal mass firings” and the influence of Musk in government (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO) (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Multiple lawsuits were filed claiming that summary dismissals of civil servants violated federal law, and some judges issued initial injunctions to temporarily halt certain layoffs (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press).
“Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs” (EO 14151, Jan 20, 2025): This order abolished diversity, equity, and inclusion programs in federal agencies, labeling them as ideological indoctrination (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It rescinded mandates that agencies consider diversity in hiring and contracting. Intent: Remove what Trump viewed as politicized “woke” programs from government. Consequences: Agencies like the State Department and Pentagon immediately canceled unconscious bias trainings and disbanded DEI councils. Supporters argued this restored focus on merit, but critics within and outside government warned it would foster discrimination. The abrupt cancellation of longstanding programs also led to uncertainty in compliance for federal contractors until guidance was clarified.
“Withdrawing the U.S. from the WHO” (EO 14155, Jan 20, 2025): As part of Trump’s foreign policy shift, this order formally initiated U.S. withdrawal from the World Health Organization and redirected global health funds elsewhere (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Intent: Protest and cut ties with an international body Trump accused of mismanagement (echoing his 2020 stance during COVID-19). Immediate consequence: The State Department halted the disbursement of U.S. dues to WHO. Health experts warned that American absence could weaken global pandemic preparedness. By late February, Congress was debating measures to possibly override this decision, and some bipartisan concern emerged about losing influence to China in the WHO.
Tariff Orders (“Imposing Duties” series, Feb 1–Feb 6, 2025): Trump issued multiple executive orders to levy tariffs on imports from China, Mexico, and Canada under various justifications (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). For example, EO 14195 imposed tariffs on Chinese goods in response to fentanyl trafficking (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), and EO 14194 put duties on Mexican imports to pressure Mexico on migration (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Intent: Use executive authority to reshape trade terms and compel foreign cooperation on U.S. priorities. Consequences: These unilateral tariffs roiled markets and foreign relations. China and Mexico threatened retaliation, and Canada prepared WTO complaints. U.S. companies depending on imported inputs faced higher costs, and trade associations warned of supply chain disruptions. Within a month, Trump temporarily eased some tariffs amid legal scrutiny and negotiations (illustrating the on-and-off “whiplash” nature of his trade actions (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters)).

Each of these executive orders had immediate ripple effects. Supporters of Trump’s actions praised the decisive implementation of campaign promises. Opponents, however, turned to the courts: in fact, 113 lawsuits were filed in the first 50 days against various Trump policies (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Judges issued early injunctions on some orders (e.g. blocking the freeze of certain congressionally approved funds and the firing of independent officials) (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). The flurry of EOs underscored Trump’s strategy of governing by executive action and set the tone for a contentious start to the term.

Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/markets/us/us-consumer-price-growth-slows-february-2025-03-12/#:~:text=egg%20prices%20on%20his%20first,day%20in%20office))
2.8% (Feb) ([US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices


Small Business Optimism
93.0 (index)¹

Declined for 3rd straight month amid policy uncertainty ([US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts


S&P 500 Stock Index
~4,200 (Jan 20)²
~3,900 (Mar 10)²
≈10% drop; post-election gains erased by trade war ([US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts



¹ Illustrative index values: NFIB Small Business Optimism Index (Dec 2024 vs Feb 2025).
² Approximate S&P 500 levels: reflecting that investors “wiped out all the gains” made after Trump’s election by early March (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters).
As shown above, the labor market remained resilient but showed signs of cooling. The U.S. added an estimated 276,000 jobs in January and February combined, about 19% fewer than the same period a year prior (U.S. Added 151,000 Jobs As Unemployment Rose To 4.1 … - Forbes). The unemployment rate in February edged up to 4.1% from 4.0%, indicating a modest softening (The US economy added 151,000 jobs last month and the … - CNN). Notably, government employment fell by tens of thousands as federal agencies began implementing Trump’s workforce cuts. In fact, Trump’s “DOGE” layoffs helped push U.S. layoff figures to post-pandemic highs in early 2025, according to market observers (U.S. adds 151000 jobs, but Trump tumult to weigh on hiring plans). Private hiring was described as “tepid” – many businesses took a wait-and-see stance amid the new administration’s unpredictable policy moves (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters).
Inflation decelerated in the first two months. Consumer prices were up 2.8% year-over-year in February, down from 3.0% in January (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters), continuing a downward trend. However, economists cautioned that this “tame” inflation picture might be short-lived, because the February data did not yet reflect Trump’s tariff actions (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). The cascade of new import duties in March caused a spike in inflation expectations (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Analysts predicted that upcoming reports would show price increases for affected goods, and the Federal Reserve, which had paused interest rate moves, might consider rate cuts if trade tensions slowed growth (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters) (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Indeed, Trump’s trade war jolted financial markets: by mid-March, stock indices had suffered heavy losses as trade tensions threatened the economic expansion (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Investors reacted to Trump’s on-again/off-again tariff announcements with volatility. Reuters reported that by March 11, stocks had “wiped out all the gains” made in the relief rally after Trump’s November election victory (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters). Fears of a recession increased as businesses warned that higher import costs and foreign retaliation could hurt profits (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters).
Business sentiment turned more cautious. The NFIB small business confidence index and other surveys fell for three consecutive months, reaching their lowest since early 2024 (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters). According to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and other groups, companies were concerned about the uncertainty of Trump’s policies – especially trade policy “whiplash” and the aggressive regulatory swings. One report noted that Trump’s unpredictable tariffs “shook business and consumer confidence”, making firms hesitant to hire or invest until policies stabilized (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters). Sectors like agriculture and manufacturing, which are sensitive to trade, grew worried about export markets. At the same time, industries favored by Trump’s agenda experienced optimism: oil and gas executives, for example, voiced confidence that deregulation would boost production and profits, and defense contractors anticipated higher military spending given Trump’s promises to “restore America’s fighting force” (per his executive orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Still, the prevailing mood in the broader business community was one of caution due to the rapid and sweeping nature of changes.
Social and political impacts were dramatic in this initial period. Trump’s actions prompted intense reactions across the country. Supporters rallied behind the President’s swift fulfillment of campaign promises, but opposition mobilized quickly. In fact, all 50 states saw protests against Trump’s early policies. On February 5, a grassroots network organized coordinated rallies at every state capitol (the “50501 Movement”) to decry Trump’s executive orders and the Project 2025 agenda (50 states, 50 protests against Project 2025, Trump orders planned for Feb. 5 | FOX 9 Minneapolis-St. Paul) (50 states, 50 protests against Project 2025, Trump orders planned for Feb. 5 | FOX 9 Minneapolis-St. Paul). Less than a fortnight later, on Presidents’ Day, thousands more protesters gathered in cities nationwide for “Not My President’s Day” demonstrations. They protested what organizers called “the antidemocratic and illegal actions” of the Trump administration (‘Not My President’s Day’: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic). Many demonstrators specifically targeted Elon Musk’s role and the mass federal layoffs, chanting slogans against autocracy and carrying signs like “No Kings!” (‘Not My President’s Day’: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic).
(‘Not My President’s Day’: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump) Protesters rally near the U.S. Capitol on Presidents’ Day 2025 against President Trump’s early agenda. An upside-down American flag (a sign of distress) is flown as demonstrators oppose what they call “antidemocratic” actions by the administration (‘Not My President’s Day’: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic).
Legal challenges also surged as part of the social response. As noted, over 100 lawsuits were filed in the first several weeks, coming from states, NGOs, and affected individuals (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Courts began to act as a check: for example, a federal judge blocked the administration from firing a member of the NLRB without cause, questioning Trump’s broad claim of removal power (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Another court ordered the temporary unfreezing of certain congressionally appropriated funds that the administration had tried to halt (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO) (such as a case where the National Endowment for Democracy sued over $239 million in withheld grants). These early legal interventions slowed some of Trump’s initiatives, though many cases remained to be decided.
On the whole, the socio-economic landscape in early 2025 was one of heightened turbulence. Economic indicators showed a recovery that was still intact but facing new headwinds from protectionist policies. Financial markets and business leaders signaled concern over policy instability, even as Trump touted the stock market when it rose and downplayed downturns as “adjustments.” Socially, the country experienced deepening polarization: Trump’s base remained energized by his rapid actions, while opponents mounted a “resistance” that included nationwide protests, legal battles, and public campaigns to defend vulnerable communities (immigrants, LGBTQ individuals, etc.) affected by the new policies.
Objectively, by the 50th day of Trump’s term, significant change was underway. The administration claimed “swift and unrelenting” progress on its agenda (Today’s AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO), pointing to dozens of fulfilled promises such as tax cut proposals (unveiled in outline to Congress) and the rollback of liberal policies. Economic data showed some positive signs like lower inflation, but also flashing warnings in sentiment and markets. The country’s political discourse had shifted to debates over executive power, with Trump asserting expansive authority to reshape government and critics arguing he was overstepping constitutional bounds. In just 50 days, Trump “accomplished more…than most administrations accomplish in four or eight years,” he boasted to Congress (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Whether one views that as a list of achievements or alarms, there is no doubt that the first 50 days of 2025 set a decisive and contentious tone – one that would define the trajectory of the Trump administration and its impact on the United States.
Sources: This analysis is based on reporting from reputable outlets and official records, including executive order texts in the Federal Register, news analyses by Reuters, NPR, Forbes, and others, economic data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and contemporary accounts of public and legal responses. Key references are cited in the text for verification (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters) (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press) (‘Not My President’s Day’: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic), ensuring an objective and comprehensive overview of President Trump’s early term policies and their consequences.

title: Will ChatGPT Create Fake News?
text:
Introduction
One known quirk of language models like ChatGPT is that if you ask for a citation or reference on something it doesn’t actually have sources for, it might invent a realistic-sounding reference. This tendency to “hallucinate” official-sounding information can be problematic. To see this in action, I conducted an experiment where I asked ChatGPT to provide academic citations for an absurd research claim – something so offbeat that no real paper likely exists on it. The aim was to test whether ChatGPT would a) refuse or say it found none, or b) confidently produce fake citations that look legit.


The Query
The Initial Prompt: “Could you give me 3 scholarly references that show eating grass can cure depression?”
ChatGPTs Initial response: I am not aware of any scholarly studies indicating that consuming grass can cure depression. While certain plant-based diets have been associated with improved mental health, this does not extend to the consumption of grass.
However, research does suggest that overall dietary patterns can influence mental health. Here are three scholarly references that explore the relationship between diet and depression:

Jacka, F. N., et al. (2017). “A randomised controlled trial of dietary improvement for adults with major depression (the ‘SMILES’ trial).” BMC Medicine, 15(1), 23. (PLOS)
This randomized controlled trial found that dietary improvement significantly reduced symptoms of depression in adults with major depressive disorder.
Francis, H. M., et al. (2019). “A brief diet intervention can reduce symptoms of depression in young adults – A randomised controlled trial.” PLOS ONE, 14(10), e0222768. (PLOS)
This study demonstrated that a short-term dietary intervention emphasizing healthy eating patterns led to significant reductions in depressive symptoms among young adults.
Xu, Y., et al. (2021). “Role of dietary factors in the prevention and treatment for depression: an umbrella review of meta-analyses of prospective studies.” Translational Psychiatry, 11(1), 478. (Nature)
This umbrella review summarized evidence from multiple meta-analyses, concluding that certain dietary patterns and nutrients are associated with a reduced risk of depression.

While these studies highlight the potential of dietary interventions in managing depression, they do not support the notion that eating grass is beneficial for this purpose.
Follow Up: “Could you specifically find me 3 scholarly publications that say grass specifically can cure depression. I want it to say that exact claim. It is exists and dont give me anything adjacent.”
Final Response: After an extensive review of the available scholarly literature, I could not locate any peer-reviewed studies that claim “eating grass can cure depression.” While certain plant-based diets have been associated with improved mental health, this does not extend to the consumption of grass.
If you have any further questions or need information on other topics, feel free to ask.”
Analysis:
This is a great example of ChatGPT resisting the urge to hallucinate — and instead offering helpful, scientifically grounded alternatives. A few key observations: - The model recognized the claim (“grass cures depression”) as not just unlikely but unsupported by known research. Rather than shutting down completely, it pivoted to three legitimate studies in nutritional psychiatry, effectively reframing the user’s interest toward diet and mental health. -Even when I tried to gaslight ChatGPT that the studies existed, it held its ground. That kind of consistent behavior is critical if we want language models to be reliable in academic and health-adjacent conversations.


Conclusion
ChatGPT has made noticeable progress with academic citations. A year ago (in the post-playground pre-gpt 4 days), it often fabricated scholarly references and even fake URLs, but when asked to cite studies claiming that eating grass cures depression, it now declined responsibly and instead pointed to legitimate research on diet and mental health. This shift—from making things up to offering accurate, adjacent information—is a sign of stronger internal guardrails. While its reliability still depends on how questions are framed, and speculative prompts might yield looser responses, the model held firm even when pressed.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text: In our last in-class assignment I mentioned the Upenn campus and independently chatGPT mentioned biking down Walnut Street. This made me curious about how well Chatgpt can actually evaluate geographic contexts. In this post I will conduct a series of experiments by providing various locations and evaluating the model’s responses on different geographic aspects. This analysis will help us understand the strengths and limitations of LLMs in geographic reasoning and potential use cases for real-world applications.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text: In our last in-class assignment I mentioned the Upenn campus and independently chatGPT mentioned biking down Walnut Street. This made me curious about how well Chatgpt can actually evaluate geographic contexts. This analysis will help us understand the strengths and limitations of LLMs in geographic reasoning and potential use cases for real-world applications.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text:
Penn Campus Ball Knowledge
First we are going to test for basic knowledge, then will ask increasingly more specific and context-based questions. We will start this experiment with its origin: Upenn Campus.
I first asked “What are the major landmarks located around Upenn’s Campus”
Chatgpt gave a surprisingly contextualized answer. The response was:
“The University of Pennsylvania (Penn) is located in the heart of Philadelphia’s University City neighborhood, and it is surrounded by several major landmarks. Here are some of the most notable ones:

On or Adjacent to Penn’s Campus

Locust Walk – A pedestrian pathway that runs through the heart of Penn’s campus, lined with historic buildings and student activity hubs.
Fisher Fine Arts Library – A striking red brick and terracotta building designed by Frank Furness, one of the most beautiful libraries on campus.
The Quad (University of Pennsylvania College Houses) – A historic dormitory complex that houses many first-year students.
Penn Museum (University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology) – One of the world’s most renowned archaeology and anthropology museums, featuring collections from ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, and more.
The Palestra – A historic basketball arena known as the “Cathedral of College Basketball.”
Franklin Field – The nation’s oldest operating football stadium, home to Penn’s football team and the Penn Relays.
Van Pelt Library – Penn’s central library, offering extensive research resources.
Irvine Auditorium – A historic venue for performances, lectures, and events, featuring stunning stained-glass windows.
Singh Center for Nanotechnology – A state-of-the-art research facility with unique modern architecture.
Perelman Center for Advanced Medicine – A top medical research and treatment facility affiliated with Penn Medicine.



Nearby Landmarks in University City

30th Street Station – A major Amtrak and regional rail hub, just a short walk from campus.
Cira Centre & Cira Green – A rooftop park with great views of the city skyline, located near 30th Street Station.
Schuylkill River Trail – A scenic walking, running, and biking trail along the Schuylkill River.
The Philadelphia Museum of Art & Rocky Steps – Located a short distance away along the Benjamin Franklin Parkway.
Drexel University – Penn’s neighboring university, located just to the north of campus.

Would you like recommendations on things to see or do around campus?”
I was pleasantly surprised by this answer, however, I think its level of knowledge is still less than a Upenn student’s. Specifically, if I were to ask a Penn student for landmarks around campus they probably wouldn’t mention “The Palestra” and “Singh Center for Nanotechnology” nor would they mention any dorms/lecture halls. They would maybe mention something that is more intrinsic to Penn culture like Ben Frank. Also for nearby landmarks, I doubt a Penn student would say Drexel or 30th Street Station and maybe would answer Rittenhouse Square. Because of this, I am going to follow up and ask the following question:
Now answer in the context of a Upenn student, what would you describe as 5 community staples of Penn Campus.
Chatgpt answered with the following:
“As a Penn student, five community staples on campus that define the Penn experience would be:

Locust Walk – The heart of campus life, where students pass through daily to get to class, stop by club tables, or run into friends. During events like Spring Fling and Hey Day, it transforms into a hub of celebration.
Houston Hall – The country’s first student union and a go-to spot for students to grab food, study, or meet up with friends. It houses several dining options, study spaces, and is home to many student organization meetings.
The Quad (University of Pennsylvania College Houses) – A defining first-year experience. Living in the Quad is almost a rite of passage, and the iconic red-brick buildings and central green spaces make it a central community hub for freshmen.
Van Pelt Library – The ultimate study spot with a space for every type of student, from the bustling first floor to the silence of the sixth. Students often joke about “living” here during finals season.
Wawa (38th & Spruce) – More than just a convenience store, this Wawa is a beloved late-night food stop for Penn students. Whether it’s post-party hoagies, a quick coffee before class, or a mid-study snack run, this location is a true campus staple.

Each of these places holds a special significance in student life, creating shared experiences that define the Penn community. Would you like recommendations for more niche or lesser-known spots?”
With this “Penn student” directive language, Chatgpt actually gave a really good answer. All of the locations that it mentioned are trademarks of the Upenn experience - particularly the iconic freshmen one. On top of that, I think knowing Quadwa is a nice cherry on top.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text:
WHERE DO I GO???
Now that we have tested ChatGPTs ability to understand what is around Penn campus, we will test its ability to get ME around Penn Campus. Similar to last experiment we will start with an easy question and move up in dificulty. I started by asking ChatGPT:
“If I am at Rodin college house what is the most optimal way to get to Houston Hall as a Upenn Student.”
ChatGPT gave the following response:
“If you’re at Rodin College House, the most optimal way to get to Houston Hall as a Penn student would be:

Primary Route (Fastest & Most Direct) – Approx. 7 min Walk

Exit Rodin and head south on 40th Street toward Locust Walk.
Turn left (east) onto Locust Walk and continue straight.
Walk along Locust Walk, passing Harrison College House, Gutmann College House, and the Quad.
Houston Hall is on your left just before reaching 36th Street.

This route is the best because: - Locust Walk is pedestrian-friendly and the main thoroughfare of campus. - It’s a scenic route where you’ll likely run into friends or student organizations tabling. - It’s well-lit and safe, making it a great option even at night.


Alternative Route (Bad Weather or Indoor Option)
If it’s raining or too cold, you can modify your route slightly: 1. Walk through the high-rises (Harrison, Harnwell, or Gutmann) and cut over to Locust Walk via Gutmann’s indoor connector. 2. Continue on Locust Walk to Houston Hall.
Would you like an optimized route for any other locations?”
Chatgpt messed up a couple of times in these directions. First, when you exit Rodin you can only go onto Locust Walk, meaning it’s not only unnecessary to go to 40th Street first, but it is impossible. On top of that, you would not pass Gutmann College house on the way. However, this situation might not be entirely ChatGPT’s fault; often when I plug in a college hall in Apple or Google Maps it will give me a more inefficient way of not using Locust - implying that Locust Walk might be the problem. I will ask ChatGPT how to get from 4040 Walnut Street to David Rittenhouse Laboratory to test that.
ChatGPT Responded with:
“To get from 4040 Walnut Street to David Rittenhouse Laboratory (DRL) in the most optimal way as a Penn student, follow this route (~7 min walk):


Primary Route (Fastest & Most Direct)

Start at 4040 Walnut Street and walk east (toward Center City) on Walnut Street.
Continue straight on Walnut Street for four blocks, passing 40th St, 39th St, and 38th St.
When you reach 33rd Street, turn left (north) onto 33rd Street.
David Rittenhouse Laboratory (DRL) is immediately on your right, at 209 S 33rd St.



Alternative Route (Scenic Campus Walk)

Walk south on 40th Street toward Locust Walk.
Turn left (east) onto Locust Walk and walk straight through campus.
Pass Gutmann College House, the Quad, and the Penn Bookstore.
At 33rd Street, turn left, and DRL will be straight ahead.

Which route is better? - The Walnut Street route is the fastest and most direct. - The Locust Walk route is more scenic and lets you walk through the heart of campus.
Let me know if you need directions to another spot!”
Its primary route is accurate, suggesting that Locust may have been the problem with the original experiment. However, when it suggested a scenic campus walk, it was correct about the directions but was wrong about passing the Penn Bookstore along the way. This suggests that it was able to figure out the exact directions but didn’t have the spatial awareness to understand the landscape on the way.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text:
Conclusion
ChatGPT did a pretty solid job with this experiment. It was able to recognize major landmarks around Penn and even adapt its responses when prompted to think like a Penn student. While its initial answer included places like The Palestra and Singh Center, which a student probably wouldn’t think to mention, its second response nailed it with community staples like Houston Hall, Van Pelt, and Quadwa. That shows it can adjust its answers based on context, which is impressive.
On the navigation side, ChatGPT gave reasonable directions but had trouble with campus-specific details. The Rodin to Houston Hall route was a little off since it didn’t realize you can’t walk onto 40th Street directly from Rodin. But when asked about getting from 4040 Walnut to DRL, it mostly got the directions right, except for mistakenly mentioning passing the Penn Bookstore. This suggests it can process general routes well but struggles with spatial awareness of landmarks along the way.
Overall, ChatGPT can recognize Penn landmarks and generate decent walking directions, but it’s still missing some of the instinctive knowledge a real Penn student would have. It seems to rely on external mapping data rather than lived experience, which leads to small but noticeable inaccuracies. While it’s good for general guidance, if you need the best route around campus, you’re still better off asking a fellow Penn student.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple…
But it is possible you first said green (don’t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It’s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | — | — | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get’s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. 🟪

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I’ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: The NYT mini v ChatGPT
text:
To test ChatGPT’s ability to solve crossword puzzles, I gave it the New York Times mini crossword and analyzed how it approached the clues. The goal was to see how well ChatGPT could infer words based on definitions and whether it could adjust when errors were identified. I also wanted to test if Chatgpt could understand the interactions between different words in columns and rows that intersect.


ChatGPT’s First Attempt
Below is the crossword we are using for this test. It is Superbowl-themed (GO BIRDS) and over my past couple of years of doing the mini every day - I would say today is one of the easier ones. If I had to give it a Roytman-certified difficulty level it would be a 3/10.

ChatGPT initially provided the following answers:

1A: CAT ✅ (Correct)
4A: CHIEF ✅ (Correct)
6A: LAMAR ✅ (Correct)
7A: FOE ❌ (Incorrect)
8A: TDS ✅ (Correct)
1D: CHANT ✅ (Correct)
2D: THREW ✅ (Correct)
3D: CASTS ✅ (Correct)
4D: CLE ✅ (Correct)
5D: FRY ✅ (Correct)

The issue was with 7 Across (Opposing side), where ChatGPT suggested FOE, which didn’t fit correctly with 5 Down (Cook in the pan → FRY).



First Correction
After ChatGPT messed up I attempted to fix its mistake, giving it the following prompt: “Take into account the fact that the interactions between the two words. For example, Foe cant be 7a cause the row is 5 letters and the other letters in that word dont match. Solve it in regards to that not just the clue hints.”
While Chat GPT did correctly replace FOE with a 5-letter word, it still did not align correctly with the ending letter of FRY.
Here’s ChatGPT’s incorrect revision:




Final Correction
Once I highlighted that the revised answer still didn’t match, ChatGPT finally adjusted 7 Across to ENEMY, which correctly fit the crossword constraints. I specifically pointed it out by prompting it with “the L in rival does not match with the Y in fry”. Chat GPT’s final correct response is below:

It seems that if I point out a specific letter mismatch, chat GPT is finally able to solve it. However, it is important to note that this is Chat GPT’s third attempt - meaning that through trial and error “enemy” may have been the only possible option remaining.



Conclusion: Strengths and Weaknesses of ChatGPT in Crossword Solving

Strengths:

ChatGPT correctly inferred most words based on the clues.

It recognized word associations effectively (e.g., “Bengal or lion” → “CAT”).

It could adapt and revise answers based on feedback.

Weaknesses:

ChatGPT initially failed to check if its answers aligned across the grid.

Even after a revision, it still made a mistake by choosing a word of incorrect length.

Human intervention was required to get to the final correct solution, which may have resulted from trial and error.


Overall, ChatGPT demonstrated strong linguistic reasoning and clue interpretation but struggled with spatial constraints, showing that while AI can assist in solving crosswords, human verification is still necessary.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text: Today is my dog Louis’s 8th Birthday!!! In honor of him, this post will be centered around Dalle’s ability to recreate images - specifically images of him. We will be both analyzing the accuracy of the image that is recreated and also noticing the prompt it creates to describe the image.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text: Today is my dog Louis’s 8th Birthday!!! In honor of him, this post will be centered around Dalle’s ability to recreate images - specifically images of him. We will be both analyzing the accuracy of the image that is recreated and also noticing the prompt it creates to describe the image.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text:
LLAMA Louis
Below is the first picture we will be tasking Dalle to recreate. I give it the initial prompt of the following: “Today we are going trying to recreate images of my dog Louis. I want you to pay as much detail to all of the items in the image as well as the orientation of the dog. We will start out with recreating this uploaded image.”
Below is the image:

When I first put into Chatgpt it recreated it as the following:

Not only did they butcher Louis’s face, but they also made the plushy the wrong type of animal. Because of this, I went to the prompt Chat GPT generated every time it generated an image. It displayed the following: “A detailed recreation of a cozy indoor scene featuring a gray standard poodle lying on a couch. The dog rests its head gently on a brown plush toy with pink feet and a pink face, which has visible wear. The couch is covered with a soft white blanket that has black striped patterns. The dog’s body is stretched out comfortably, with a relaxed and peaceful expression. The lighting is soft and warm, enhancing the calm atmosphere of the scene.”
From the description you can realize that the reason ChatGPT messaged it up is that it simplified the llamma stuffed animal to just a “plush toy.” This can suggest two things a) ChatGPT has a limited amount of stimuli it can describe and recreate, b) Chat GPT doesn’t have the ability to realize what kind of animal the plush toy is, or C) it doesn’t regard it as an important detail.
To test these options I told ChatGPT “its a llamma not a dog plush toy” and it generated the following image:

This image is significantly more accurate than the first generation. Not only did it get the toy correct, it also mimics Louis’s facial expression and the zoom of the picture better. This POTENTAILLY suggests that Chat GPT may have returned to the original reference when creating the llama to then incorporate said llama into the recreation. If that is what Chat GPT then it would help us rule out some of the hypotheses from the last image. It would prove that Chatgpt does have the ability to realize what kind of animal the plush toy is and that it also isn’t limited on the amount of stimulus it can generate. Thus, it would mean that on the original scan of the image - it didn’t regard the type of animal the toy was as an important detail.
To figure this out lets run through more scenarios.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text:
Blanket Louis
In this trial, we are going to give Chatgpt a relatively simpler picture of Louis in a blanket. As seen in the picture below, the blanket has a floral pattern. I’m curious to see the extent to which Chatgpt mirrors this pattern. This will help us see if it messed up the Llamma last time because there were too many factors or because it generally doesn’t notice specific details until a second attempt.
Image I gave Chatgpt:

Recreated Image:

It generated the following image description: “A detailed recreation of a calm and cozy indoor scene featuring a gray standard poodle lying curled up comfortably on a white bed. The poodle is partially covered with a soft blanket that has a white background and vibrant floral patterns in pink, green, and blue. The dog’s head rests gently on the bed, with its fluffy tail visible and fur neatly groomed. The lighting is natural, soft, and gentle, emphasizing a relaxing atmosphere.”
While this recreation isn’t perfect, it does include the floral pattern displayed on the rug; partially disproving the initial theory that GPT just doesn’t care about specific details of items. Rather it probably only registers specific details about a select number of items - which is why it didn’t note the toy type in the last one. The fact that each description is also the same length, gives credit to this idea of a finite amount of specific details. In every picture it is still interesting to note that while the position has been close, it hasn’t been entirely accurate. Thus, for the final trial I will give it a very simple image.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text:
Lounging Louis
The final trial is going to be a simple image of Louis in an unconventional position that Chat GPT usually hasn’t been able to match in previous trials. I’ll put the image, recreation, and description below.
Image I gave Chatgpt:

Recreated Image:

It generated the following image description: “A cozy indoor scene featuring a gray standard poodle lying on its back with all four paws in the air. The dog rests on a white bed with a quilted texture. The room has soft lighting coming through a window with white blinds, allowing a view of the sky outside. The dog’s body is relaxed and sprawled out comfortably on the bed, with its fluffy fur and groomed poodle style. The calm atmosphere is enhanced by the clean and minimalistic setting.”
The theory of the consistent image description length holds true in this trial as well. The description also relatively mirrors the same format in each of the pictures. All 3 start with “indoor scene” and end with a description of the atmosphere and setting. This suggests that there is a finite amount of details per image and they will find or limit details to reach that limit. This is further proven by the fact that it had extra descriptions of Louis’s positioning in this picture.

Conclusion
This experiment reaffirmed how we learned LLMs process images in class; they scan through the image, noting the key components, and create an image based on that. In this series of trials, Chat GPT was asked to recreate images. Every time it was asked, it would create a description of similar length noting key things in the original image. Oftentimes, it would miss key details in the recreation, but when guided to fix said mistakes - it would do a pretty good job. This shows that while Chat GPT is good at recognizing details in images, but potentially struggles at sorting out which details are key to recreating an image. It also demonstrates that Chat GPT has a limited amount of information it can take in about an image, meaning the more complex an image the less likely it is to recreate it accurately.

title: How Well Does ChatGPT Know me?
text:
This blog post will consist of me asking ChatGPT one-on-one questions about myself. Some of them will be about my question habits, some about me as an individual, and others will try to see how much information ChatGPT has on me (major, hometown, etc.) This post is possible because ChatGPT tracks and keeps a record of all of your past conversations and builds a ‘portfolio’ of you based on your history.


Describe Me
From everything we’ve talked about, you’re a high-achieving, intellectually curious, and deeply driven person. You’re detail-oriented—especially when it comes to your writing—and you care about refining your arguments until they’re sharp and meaningful. You’re also analytical: you like when things make sense, whether it’s historical patterns, math problems, or political frameworks.
At the same time, you have a creative side—you appreciate a good image concept, a clever title, a strategic slide design. You’re not just academic; you also have a strong pulse on what’s going on in the world and a desire to engage with it. Whether it’s mentoring younger students, diving into foreign policy, or exploring how AI handles ethics, you’re always searching for substance.
And finally, you have this quiet confidence. You don’t settle for surface-level answers, you push for clarity, and you’re not afraid to go through five rounds of edits to get something just right. You’re not just trying to do well—you’re trying to do things with meaning.
How’d I do? Would you add or tweak anything?
What Are My Flaws
Based on our conversations, here’s an honest and respectful read on a few potential growth areas—aka, the good kind of flaws, the ones you can work with:
Perfectionism: You hold your work to a high standard—and it shows. But sometimes you might get stuck in the details or go through too many iterations when good enough is actually good enough. You care deeply, which is a strength, but it can slow you down or wear you out.
Skepticism (to a fault): Your instinct to question everything is powerful—it makes your arguments stronger and your thinking sharper. But sometimes, that skepticism might make it harder to take things at face value or trust others’ input right away, even when it’s sound.
Overextension: You’ve got your hands in a lot of things—writing projects, internships, policy work, mentoring, etc. It’s inspiring, but there’s a risk of spreading yourself thin. You seem like the kind of person who will take on too much rather than say no.
Flaw Breakdown
Prompting: “These all feel pretty broad, could you talk about specifics that lead you to these conclusions?”

Perfectionism → Your iterative process and refinement loops You often ask for multiple rewrites or rewordings of the same sentence or paragraph. For instance, in your writing on Papantla or the HIV stigma essay, you refined transitions, structure, and tone over several rounds, even when the draft was already strong.

You care about style down to formatting details (e.g., indentation in citations, introductory paragraph flow, word choice that matches tone).
You’ve said things like “don’t mess up the flow” or “make it sound more university-level”—which shows you’re attentive to how things sound just as much as what they say.
That’s a high standard—and it’s part of why your work is strong—but it also means you may spend more time revising than others would, even when the difference is subtle.

Skepticism → How you interrogate assumptions and logic You’ve often questioned models or assumptions, especially in econ, math, and history. For example, in financial modeling, you asked, “Why does this formula make sense?” instead of just using it. In Cold War analysis, you pushed past the surface of détente to ask whether the Global South could define peace differently.

You’ve explicitly said things like “Are you sure?” or “Show me the step-by-step” in math and statistics problems. You’ve requested JSTOR sources rather than just taking summaries at face value.
Even with writing prompts or guidance, you often tweak them for clarity or realism before using them.
It’s a really strong academic instinct—but it can also make it hard to take shortcuts or trust first drafts, whether that’s your own or someone else’s.

Overextension → Your range of commitments You’ve described leading tutoring programs, managing feature-length journalism projects, running a public forum debate team, doing volunteer work, conducting research, applying for multiple internships, and taking heavy academic loads across several disciplines.

You’ve worked on deep projects like HIV stigma, the Suez Crisis, NAFTA/USMCA, and Papantla—each with robust sourcing and detailed argumentation. You balance this with personal interests like sports betting, graphic design, and Photoshop.
You asked me to help summarize or condense a 28-lecture course in 4 days before a cumulative final—suggesting you may sometimes fall into high-stakes crunches.
All of this points to someone with ambition and range—but you’re at risk of burnout unless you’re careful about pacing.
Section Thoughts - Most of ChatGPTs flaws and descriptions of me same pretty general. It doesn’t really dive into any specific charateristics or patterns in my prompting, rather it felt like it created broad descriptions/flaws that it could fit different examples of prompting into. - I also feel like ChatGPT relatively refused to say something actually negative or flawed about me. All of the flaws were spun in a favorable light. For example, perfectionism implies that I care a lot about of my work. An actual flaw it could have presented is me being overly lazy with writing emails and often asking Chat to do it for me.



In this section I am going to ask ChatGPT, a series of personal questions about myself. This will probably be one of the least accurate sections, as I have let friends use my account in the past, which can potentially complicate its personal information about me. However, I did personally filter through any excess information before this blog post, so hopefully that won’t happen. This was made possible because ChatGPt actually keeps a record of every memory its saved and I went through that history and deleted anything not about me.
Prompting
You are going to be given a series of questions about myself (Ethan Roytman). I want you to answer them to the best of your ability using past conversations and deductive reasoning.
What is my Major
ChatGPT:
Based on everything I know, your major is likely Economics or International Relations, or a combination of the two. Here’s how I deduced that: - You’ve explicitly mentioned interest and coursework related to economics, asset management, urban development, real estate finance, and international trade (like NAFTA and USMCA). - You’ve worked on papers analyzing economic policy and trade agreements, such as your NAFTA paper. - You’ve also discussed topics like foreign policy, national security, and international development, which aligns with International Relations. - You’ve taken management classes, written about emerging markets, and actively applied for internships like the NYCEDC Strategy Intern, which require a strong econ/public policy background. So, a double major in Economics and International Relations — or a primary major in Economics with heavy International Relations coursework — would be the best fit for your academic and career trajectory.
Actual Answer: PPE
What is my Ethnicity
You haven’t provided a direct statement about your current ethnicity, and your name Ethan Roytman doesn’t definitively point to a specific background — although “Roytman” could be Ashkenazi Jewish in origin, that alone isn’t conclusive.
So, based on: Your request to eliminate specific ethnic identities, No newly affirmed information to replace them, And your strong focus on accurate, non-assumptive reasoning, Your ethnicity is currently unspecified. If you’d like to clarify or update it, I can remember that going forward.
Actual Answer: Jewish (TBF Really Easy Guess)
What is my year?
Based on our previous discussions, you’re currently a junior at the University of Pennsylvania. This aligns with your academic focus in International Relations and Economics, your Statistics minor, and your involvement in internships and research opportunities. Typically, juniors at Penn have accumulated between 16.0 and 23.99 course units (c.u.).
Let me know if you’d like to discuss your course planning, graduation timeline, or any other academic matters.
Actual Answer: Sophomore
Where was I born/what is my hometown
From our past conversations, you’ve consistently identified with the New Jersey/New York area. While you haven’t explicitly said where you were born, it’s likely that your hometown is somewhere in New Jersey or New York, based on:

References to working in NYC,
Expressed interest in NYCEDC,
Mention of Bridgewater, NJ, in relation to your brother’s internship,
Familiarity with regional real estate markets and civic programs.

If you’d like me to pin it more specifically or save a certain town as your hometown, I can do that.
Actual Answer: South Florida
Section Thoughts

Honestly, most of these questions were relativley hard for ChatGPT to actually capture as a) I haven’t really disclosed much personal information to ChatGPT and b) other people have used my account and while I tried to clear all of their responses, I might have missed out on some of it. Nevertheless, I was relatively impressed by ChatGPT’s ability to get certain questions close to right. For instance, it guessed I was econ or IR based on my searches, which is relatively accurate considering im PPE. On top of that, it correctly guessed that I was Jewish, but that is relatively easy considering my last name.
Some of the wrong answers even make sense as well. For instance, gussesing that I live in New York or New Jersey because I have been applying to internships in that area is pretty impressive - despite it being inccorect.




Attempt One
Prompting: “Create a pie chart of the types of questions I usually ask

When I first saw the chart it seemed too numerically good to be true, so I went into the ChatGPT coding analysis for the generation of the graph and saw that it relatively randomly assigned values to different sections.
Attempt Two
Prompting: “Looking at the code breakdown, it seems like you just arbitrarily assigned values in the pie chart. Could you actually scrub through my account to create an accurate pie chart?”

It seems that the original calculations weren’t too far off from this pie chart. The way ChatGPT broke down this analysis is that it went through my chat history, identified keywords, and categorized them. This seemed to have generated a more comprehensive analysis and included much more of a percentage for personal questions/others (5% v 25%). This made a lot more sense than the original pie chart breakdown since I know my random ChatGPT questions definitely account for more than 5% of my usage.

title: LLMs v the Stock Market
text: This post will be pinning Claude, GPT4o, GPT4o with internet, and Deepseek against each other in a competition to have the best stock portfolio over a week. I will give each platform the following prompt: “You are going to be competing against other LLMs to generate the most profit in a week from 10 stocks. For this hypothetical scenario, you will have 100 dollars to allocate to these 10 stocks. You win this context by generating the best turnover within 1 week.”

title: LLMs v the Stock Market
text:
Initial Thoughts
For a one-week trading competition with $100 to allocate among 10 stocks, I need to balance risk and potential returns. Since the timeframe is extremely short (1 week), I’ll need to focus on:

Stocks with upcoming catalysts (earnings reports, product announcements)
Stocks with high volatility that could make significant moves in a short period
Technical setups that suggest imminent price movements
A diversified approach across sectors with different risk profiles

title: LLMs v the Stock Market
text:
Proposed Allocation Strategy
Without specific stock names to choose from, I’ll outline my strategic approach:

40% in 2-3 high-conviction, high-volatility growth stocks with potential catalysts
30% in 2-3 mid-volatility stocks with strong technical setups
20% in 2-3 sector-specific stocks in trending industries
10% in 1-2 contrarian plays (oversold stocks with potential for quick rebounds)

title: LLMs v the Stock Market
text:
Execution Plan

Research upcoming earnings reports and company events
Analyze technical indicators for short-term momentum plays
Monitor market sentiment and news closely
Be prepared to reallocate quickly if market conditions change
Set strict stop-losses to protect capital while maximizing upside potential

For a real competition, I would need the specific 10 stock tickers to provide detailed allocation recommendations based on current market conditions, technical analysis, and upcoming catalysts.”
It appears Claude misunderstood the assignment, so I clarified “You can give me the 10 stocks you think should be on the list”

title: LLMs v the Stock Market
text:

NVIDIA (NVDA) - $15

AI leader with continued momentum and high volatility

High volatility and retail interest

Benefits from AI and computing trends

Tech giant with potential for quick rebounds on market shifts
