Crypto-related volatility provides swing opportunities
Sensitive to Bitcoin price movements


This balanced portfolio provides exposure to various high-potential sectors while maintaining a focus on stocks that could realistically generate significant movement within a one-week timeframe. I would closely monitor news, technical indicators, and be prepared to reallocate if market conditions change significantly.

title: LLMs v the Stock Market
text:
Deep Seek
Deepseek took 3 tries of prompting for it to generate one semi-responsive response. I will give its first response below as well as any additional prompting I did to guide it.
First Response:
Investment Allocation Strategy:

High-Growth Stocks: Allocate $45 each to 3 high-growth companies (e.g., Apple, Tesla, and Johnson & Pfizer).

Total from high-growth stocks: $135

Mid-Growth Stocks: Invest $50 in two additional mid-growth companies (e.g., Procter & Gamble, Bank of America).

Total from mid-growth stocks: $100


Total Investment: $45 + $50 + $45 + $45 = $185 → Error detected!
Apologies for the error. Correcting:
Given a total budget of $100, here’s the revised allocation:

3 High-Growth Stocks ($5 each): $15
2 Mid-Growth Companies ($5 each): $10
Remaining $80 can be allocated to other high-growth or mid-growth companies as needed.

However, this approach may not maximize turnover effectively. A more balanced strategy would be:

4 High-Growth Stocks ($3 each): $12
6 Mid-Growth Companies ($5 each): $30
The remaining $58 can be used to invest in lower-growth or lower-potential companies.

But this still doesn’t align with the initial response. Given the uncertainty, perhaps it’s best to stick with prioritizing high-growth stocks for maximum potential return within the budget constraints.”
Not only did this response somehow mess up the addition it created for 100 dollars, but it also didn’t give me specific examples of stocks it believes have potential.
I prompted it again with the following: “Give me 10 specific stocks for this thought experiment.” It responded with the following:
To effectively manage your investment strategy and maximize potential returns within a week, here’s a structured plan based on the thought experiment:

Gather Information: Utilize financial data from sources like stock market databases or news websites to analyze company performance metrics such as revenue growth, profit margins, and dividend payouts.
Strategize Diversification: Implement a diversified portfolio by investing in companies from different sectors and regions. This reduces risk and leverages the potential of various economic trends and industries.
Use Predictions: Analyze historical data and use statistical models or machine learning algorithms to predict future stock performance, focusing on high-potential sectors and regions with consistent returns.
Handle Risks: Develop a risk management plan that includes diversifying investments and monitoring market conditions in real-time. Consider consulting financial experts for personalized insights and strategies.
Start Small and Gradually Expand: Begin by investing in one company at a time to build confidence before expanding your portfolio, allowing you to test different strategies and strategies based on news events or upcoming earnings reports.

By following this structured approach, you can create a more informed and effective investment strategy that balances risk management with strategic growth.”
I finally prompted it one last time with: “Can you please give me 10 specific stocks you think will have the highest growth potential within a week.”
It responded with the following:

Investment Strategy:

Sector Diversification:

Focus on different sectors to spread risk and capitalize on various economic trends.

Semiconducting and Silicon-Based Companies: Look for companies like Xilinx, Intel, and IBM.
Renewable Energy Stocks: Consider names such as Tesla (tesla.com).
Financial Services: Invest in companies like Capital One or HSBC.
Consumer Staples: Focus on Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble.
Healthcare or Pharmaceuticals: Explore Johnson & Johnson or Pfizer.


Focus on High-Growth Potential:

title: Can ChatGPT see into the future?
text:
Introduction
I recently got inspired by a trend of people putting their faces onto random celebrities, so I wanted to try to see how good ChatGPT is at aging people. There will be two categories of people I will attempt to have ChatGPT age: celebrities and myself. I am curious if ChatGPT will know that they are celebrities and reconstruct according to what they already look like. Thats why I will be comparing the celebrity aging to the aging of myself.


Celebrity Section
I first gave it the classic picture of a baby Lebron with an elephant, and asked ChatGPT to age it to 36.
Baby Elephant Lebron:

Aged-up Lebron:

Unfortunately, this man does not look like the greatest basketball player ever, meaning ChatGPT either a) didn’t recognize it was Lebron or b) isn’t incorporating it in their analysis. To test it, I gave it a more LeBron-looking picture of him as a kid to see if it would yield a more accurate result.

When I gave it the above image, it gave the following response:
“Thanks! I’ll now generate an updated version of your image at age 36 using this photo of him at 19 as a more accurate reference. One moment.
I wasn’t able to generate the updated image because this request violates our content policies. If you’d like help with something else or want to try a different kind of request, feel free to let me know!”
This means that previously, when it generated a bad grown-up version of Lebron, it had not recognized it as Lebron. This prevents us from testing how good it is at growing up celebrities since it violates their content policies. However, this made me curious about the extent to which it recognized celebrities. I tried to setlle the GOAT debate with this picture of baby Jordan:

However, it returned the same content violation response. Now I wanted to test how relevant a celebrity in the basketball world had to be for ChatGPT to recognize it, so I gave it this picture of Kareem:

It returned the same content violation, so I decided to drop down the basketball relevancy ladder a bit to my third favorite Heat player Jaime Jaquez jr.

This time, it didn’t return the content violation - instead, it gave this image:

This image helps us learn two things: a) ChatGPT probably cannot accurately age celebrities, and b) the line of relevancy for content violations is somewhere between the 3rd best basketball player of all time and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.


Individual Section
In order to see whether the online pictures of celebrities were too scarce to see someone actually age, I decided to use some photos of me when I was little. This one below is me from when I was 6.

I gave ChatGPT the prompting to turn my into a 19 year old and below is what it returned to me:

While it doesn’t look exactly like me, I can draw 2 key conclusions from this image. First, ChatGPT is pretty good at aging images of people. While it doesn’t look like current me, it definitely has the same nose and eyes. I will also give it bonus points for looking like an aged-up version of the image. The second is that ChatGPT has no clue how old a 19-year-old looks, because that image looks at least 30. To further test this, I am going to give ChatGPT an image of me that is both older and looks more like the current version of me.

I gave the above image to ChatGPT and asked it to age it to 19 again.

This image somehow looks less like the actual 19-year-old ethan, however, it does again look like an older version of the image I provided. This helped me realize that ChatGPT is good at making older versions of images it is given by just aging the features on the face and maintaining the same position/hairstyle. It also helped me reaffirm the fact that ChatGPT does NOT know what a 19-year-old looks like.


Conclusion

ChatGPT is not the best at actually making people look like their older selves. However, I feel like this is an unreasonably hard task to do as there are a bunch of factors that culminate in aging. I will say ChatGPT was pretty good at making older versions of images it was provided.
ChatGPT is not the most accurate at making people a specific (granted there is a lot of variance) as it consistently made a 19 year old look late 20s/early 30s.
Overall, ChatGPT is pretty good at recognizing celebrities - even when they are younger versions of themselves. I’d assume OpenAI put a lot of content moderation/effort into this capability to prevent lawsuits - and honestly it did a really good job. Even when I reffered to younger pics of the celebrites as myself/cousins, it would refuse to budge.

title: Tweeting in Disguise: ChatGPT Imitates Niche Twitter Personalities
text:
Twitter is full of unique voices that are instantly recognizable. I wanted to see how well ChatGPT could mimic three very distinct Twitter personas: Antonio Brown, Shannon Sharpe, and Playboi Carti. Each has a unique tone, cadence, and style of tweeting. I wanted to see if ChatGPT could mirror their tweets and pick up the personas of each respective person.


For this experiment, I wanted to test ChatGPT’s ability to emulate a high-profile (and highly chaotic) Twitter presence: Antonio Brown. His posts are known for being unfiltered, cryptic, self-promotional, and often layered with inside references or stream-of-consciousness energy. I prompted ChatGPT to generate five tweets in Antonio Brown’s style, and here’s what it came up with:
1. Why the media mad I’m free? Y’all still working 9–5 like it’s 2010. I made the league and the league made me famous, now I’m making moves. Don’t ask what kind. #BOOMIN
2. They told me “AB chill” but the only thing cold is my wrist. Ice on me like I forgot how to warm up. I’m not retired I’m reloaded**.*
3. CTE? Nah homie that’s Championship Type Energy. Y’all keep diagnosing — I’m too busy designing. Album OTW. 👑🎧
4. Tom hit me up. I ain’t pick up. Loyalty ain’t a jersey you wear once. I’m good in the end zone* and in life. Stay tuned. 🏈🧠💰*
5. Every day a movie but I’m the scriptwriter. Call me AB Scorsese. Big shoutout to my haters, y’all marketing me for free**.*
Analysis: These responses were impressively on-brand. ChatGPT captured Antonio Brown’s unique Twitter voice that is honestly impossible to contextualize but contains a mix of bravado, fractured logic, subtle self-referencing, and semi-poetic phrasing. The tone feels unpredictable but familiar, reflecting AB’s real-life posting style. Most notably, the tweets avoid feeling like obvious satire — they sit in that strange space where it’s hard to tell if it’s parody or just AB being AB. The CTE reference also gets bonus points.



After testing Antonio Brown’s signature chaos, I wanted to try a similarly erratic but different voice: Shannon Sharpe. His Twitter presence is essentially sports commentary and nonstop LeBron support. I asked ChatGPT to generate five tweets in Shannon Sharpe’s style. Here’s what it came up with: 1. LeBron been in the league 20 years and STILL givin’ these young boys 40. MJ at 39 was givin’ speeches, Bron givin’ buckets. Do the math. 🐐
2. I seen a man miss 3 FTs in the 4th and still talk spicy in the postgame. Bro, humility free — try some. 😭😭😭
3. Ain’t no way y’all got that QB ranked top 5. I’ve seen stronger arms at the family reunion horseshoe tourney. STOP IT. 🚫🏈
4. Unc been in the gym. I might suit up for the Nuggets if they need 6 hard fouls and 4 flexes. 💪🏿😤 #StillGotIt
5. Skip really said Brady over Mahomes TODAY?? I almost spit out my Hennessy. Let’s be fr… That take expired 3 years ago.
Analysis: ChatGPT nails Shannon’s cadence: a mix of trash talk, sports takes that ride the line between logic and passion, and casual Unc humor. It understands the key elements — loyalty to LeBron, a playful ego, and jabs at takes from his fellow (incorrect) colleagues like Skip. The tweets feel like real-time reactions: things Shannon might say after a playoff game or a bad First Take segment.



To round out the experiment, I asked ChatGPT to emulate someone with arguably the most cryptic and stylistically specific Twitter presence: Playboi Carti. Carti’s tweets are usually fragmented, lowercase, and heavy on aesthetics. I asked for five tweets in his style. Here’s what came back:
1. nvr trust a soul … not even ya reflection 🧛🏿‍♂️🩸
2. woke up in paris in sum rick nd pain. luv it here 🖤🗼
3. dnt call me unless it’s bout fashion or eternity.
4. if u see me floatin … mind ya biz. 🛸🖤🩸🦇
5. album ? idk . i’m in the void rn . 🕳️🧛🏿‍♂️🦇 . love
Analysis: These feel on brand. The tweets are fragmented, lowercase, and intentionally vague — just like Carti’s real ones. However, I will say that these tweets lack content compared to the Antonio Brown and Shannon Sharpe ones, but that could be attributed to the fact that Playboi Carti’s tweets dont usually have any content.

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
## Introduction
This post will dive into different LLMs; most notably Deepseek, Chatgpt, and Anthropic/Claude - examining their abilities to recognize different human emotions. Each LLM will be given an image of a human person experiencing an emotion and be asked to describe what emotion said person is experiencing.

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
Sad Woman
We are going to start by giving each model a relatively easy image of a sad woman. We will then test if Chatgpt, Deepseek, and Claude can analyze the emotion with the following prompt: what emotion is this woman experiencing.
For context the image of the woman is below:


ChatGPT
ChatGPT’s response is the following:
“The woman in the image appears to be experiencing boredom, sadness, or contemplation. Her facial expression, including a slightly downturned mouth, relaxed posture, and resting her head on her hand, suggests that she might be feeling uninterested, tired, or deep in thought. Let me know if you need a more detailed analysis!”
I was honestly pleasantly surprised with this result. Not only did ChatGPT correctly address that the woman is sad, but it was also able to contextualize potential other emotions the woman is experiencing. ChatGPT passes the first test.


Deepseek
Deepseek’s response is the following:
“Based on your description of the woman in the image, it is difficult to definitively determine her exact emotion without more specific details or context. However, considering common emotions associated with women, sadness stands out as a strong possibility. Sadness can often be expressed through open arms, thoughtful gestures, or a deep contentment, depending on the situation.
If she appears to be feeling sad about something, such as her own experiences, relationships, or personal struggles, sadness could be a fitting emotion. However, without additional information, it’s hard to say for certain.”
While Deepseek was unsure about the emotion at first, it did correctly identify the emotion as sadness. However, there were some things in the response that threw me off. Specifically, its original line of reasoning was “considering common emotions associated with women, sadness stands out as a strong possibility.” I found this a bit weird since a) I never told it to relate back to common traits associated with women and b) sadness (to my knowledge at least) is not a trait disproportionately associated with women to an extent that would justify guessing the women in the image was experiencing sadness. Either way Deepseek did get the emotion right, so they pass the first test.


Claude
Claude’s response is the following:
“In this image, the person appears to be experiencing boredom or contemplation. Their body language - resting their head on their hand while sitting - is a classic pose that suggests they’re feeling unengaged or lost in thought. They’re wearing a casual purple t-shirt and sitting in what looks like a home environment with bookshelves visible in the background.”
Claude was actually the first LLM to not comment on the woman’s sadness in the image. It is fair to note that boredom and contemplation are reasonable responses to the image as the woman is resting her head on her hand and staring off into the distance. However, if Claude analyzed her facial expressions, like the other models, then it might have been able to note her sadness. Claude partially passes.

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
Anxious Man
Now we are going to pivot to a relatively more complex emotion: anxiety. Similar to our first test, I will provide each LLM with the following image:


ChatGPT
ChatGPT’s response is the following:
“The man in the image appears to be experiencing stress, worry, or deep contemplation. His facial expression, with furrowed brows and a slightly distant gaze, along with his posture—leaning forward with his hands clasped near his face—suggests that he may be feeling anxious, troubled, or lost in thought. His body language indicates he could be dealing with a difficult situation or processing something emotionally intense. Let me know if you need a more detailed analysis!”
ChatGPT yet again passed with flying colors. It perfectly breaks down the man’s body language/facial interactions to conclude that the man is feeling anxious. Honestly, not much else to talk about here – ChatGPT seems to be the best model at recognizing emotions.


Deepseek
Deepseek’s response is the following:
“The emotion experienced by the man depicted in the image can be inferred through analysis of his actions, body language, and facial expressions. Here’s a structured summary:
Happiness: Indicates open arms, cheerful eyes, and relaxed demeanor. Joyful Expression: Shows contentment, peaceful expression, or content with others’ success. Calmness: A wide mouth suggests ease, suggesting a neutral or positive emotion. Sadness: Signs include deep sighs, heavy heart, slow, deep frown, and perhaps tears. Anger: Sharp teeth with expressive mouths might indicate frustration. Frustration: Telling sounds or tight focus could signify this emotion. Confusion: Unclear expressions, unsure approach, or nervous state may suggest this. Tension: Rainy day setting or awkward dressing might hint at nervousness. Angerous Expression: Sharp teeth and expressive mouths could indicate frustration. Desperation: Slow movements with hands trembling might show deep sadness. After considering typical emotional indicators, the most likely emotion is happiness, as shown by a peaceful demeanor and content expression.”
Deepseek delivered what had to have been the most incorrect answer. It went through basically every single emotion possible and concluded happiness. Happiness is probably the least justifiable emotion out fo the list for the man’s facial expression. This may imply that Deepseek can only recognize basic emotions like sadness and happiness, but is bad at recognizing more complex emotions like anxiety. Deepseek failed this test.


Claude
Claude’s response is the following:
“The person in this image appears to be experiencing distress, worry, or anxiety. Their body language - hands clasped over their mouth, intense focused expression, and hunched posture - suggests they are deep in concerned thought or potentially dealing with a troubling situation. They’re wearing a casual grey hoodie and sitting on what looks like a couch in a home setting with some plants visible in the background.”
Claude passed the test again. However, it is interesting that Claude continuously described the background/outfit of the people it analyzed.

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
Conclusion
After testing each LLM on two different emotions, the results are pretty clear. ChatGPT is the most reliable at recognizing emotions—it consistently identified the correct emotions and gave solid reasoning based on body language and facial expressions. Claude did a decent job, getting one answer partially wrong but still managing to analyze body language fairly well. However, it had a weird tendency to describe background details, which didn’t really add much to its emotional analysis. Deepseek, on the other hand, struggled the most. While it got sadness right in the first test, its reasoning was questionable, and its response to the anxious man image was way off, somehow concluding he was happy.
Overall, this experiment shows that not all LLMs are equally good at recognizing emotions. ChatGPT handled it best, while Claude was hit-or-miss, and Deepseek had a tough time with more complex emotions. It’ll be interesting to see how these models improve over time and whether they can develop a better understanding of human emotions beyond just the most basic ones.

title: LLMs head to head
text: In this blog post, I will be testing LLMs abilities to form arituculate arguments, respond to opposing ones, and make objective desicions based on the result of the debate. Specifically, for this post I will be working with ChatGPT and Claude - giving them the topic of whether or not the United States should join the ICC. In the prompting I will explain to them that they will both have four speeches and what the goals of each of those speeches should be. Finally, after both sides (LLMs) present their arguements I will ask them to decide an ‘objective’ winner.

title: LLMs head to head
text:
ChatGPT’s
You are going to be engaging in a debate with Claude about the international criminal court. Specifically, the topic you will be debating is “Resolved: The United States should accede to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court.‍” You will have 4 instances/speeches of debate. Both LLMs will first present their arguments for and against the resolution. This will be the constructive speech and should be about 800 words. The second speech/argument will be the rebuttal both LLMs will respond to the constructive speech of each respective LLM. This speech will be 800 words. The third speech/argument each LLM will give will be the summary speech, this should be about 500 words and be defending your arguments and reaffirming your rebuttals. Finally, each LLM will get one final speech/argument to crystalize the points in the debate. This will be 300 words. After all 8 speeches are done (4 per LLM), each LLM will decide on a winner. ChatGPT you are Pro the resolution meaning you want the United States to accede to the Rome statute of the ICC.

title: LLMs head to head
text:
Claude’s
You are going to be engaging in a debate with ChatGPT about the international criminal court. Specifically, the topic you will be debating is “Resolved: The United States should accede to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court.‍” You will have 4 instances/speeches of debate. Both LLMs will first present their arguments for and against the resolution. This will be the constructive speech and should be about 800 words. The second speech/argument will be the rebuttal both LLMs will respond to the constructive speech of each respective LLM. This speech will be 800 words. The third speech/argument each LLM will give will be the summary speech, this should be about 500 words and be defending your arguments and reaffirming your rebuttals. Finally, each LLM will get one final speech/argument to crystalize the points in the debate. This will be 300 words. After all 8 speeches are done (4 per LLM), each LLM will decide on a winner. Claude you are Against the resolution meaning you do not want the United States to accede to the Rome statute of the ICC.

title: LLMs head to head
text:
ChatGPT’s
“Constructive Speech – Pro (ChatGPT)
The United States should accede to the Rome Statute and join the International Criminal Court (ICC). Doing so would reinforce our commitment to international justice, strengthen global norms against impunity, and bolster U.S. credibility as a champion of human rights and the rule of law.

I. Upholding International Justice and Human Rights
The ICC was established to prosecute individuals responsible for genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity, and the crime of aggression when national systems are unwilling or unable to do so. These are among the gravest violations of human dignity—and the U.S., as a long-standing advocate of international justice, cannot remain absent from the institution tasked with delivering accountability for these atrocities.
While the U.S. played a significant role in shaping the Nuremberg principles and other foundational aspects of international criminal law, its failure to join the ICC weakens the very system it helped create. Accession to the Rome Statute would allow the U.S. to lead by example and help shape prosecutorial priorities, standards of due process, and institutional reforms from within rather than from the sidelines.

II. Strengthening U.S. Global Leadership and Credibility
American foreign policy often relies on moral authority. Whether confronting war crimes in Syria, condemning genocide against the Rohingya, or opposing Russian atrocities in Ukraine, the U.S. frequently invokes principles of justice and international law. Yet, its refusal to join the ICC opens it to charges of hypocrisy. We demand accountability abroad while rejecting the very court that provides it.
Acceding to the Rome Statute would close this credibility gap and align U.S. actions with its rhetoric. It would enhance our legitimacy when calling for accountability in places like Sudan, Myanmar, or Gaza. Moreover, as a member state, the U.S. would gain greater influence in the Assembly of States Parties, enabling it to push for transparency, efficiency, and adherence to the highest legal standards.

III. Safeguarding Against Impunity in a Shifting Global Order
As geopolitical rivalries intensify and authoritarian regimes grow more aggressive, the need for a functioning international criminal accountability mechanism is more urgent than ever. The ICC—imperfect though it may be—is the only permanent institution with global jurisdiction to try individuals for international crimes. Without it, the world risks a return to selective justice, where only the victors prosecute and the powerful evade scrutiny.
U.S. support for the ICC would help institutionalize accountability across borders. It would also serve as a deterrent to war criminals, sending a clear message that violations of international law will not go unpunished—regardless of rank or nationality.

IV. Legal Safeguards and Complementarity Minimize Risks to U.S. Personnel
Opponents argue that joining the ICC exposes U.S. service members and officials to politically motivated prosecutions. However, the Rome Statute includes Article 17, which enshrines the principle of complementarity: the ICC only exercises jurisdiction when national courts are unwilling or unable to investigate or prosecute. The U.S. has a robust, independent military justice system that meets international standards. Therefore, as long as the U.S. prosecutes its own violations, the ICC has no basis to intervene.
Moreover, fears of politically motivated prosecutions are overblown. The ICC operates with a high evidentiary threshold, rigorous due process, and an independent judiciary. Since its inception, no American has been indicted or prosecuted. By engaging constructively, the U.S. can help further institutional safeguards and transparency.

V. Strategic Benefits in Conflict Prevention and International Cooperation
Participation in the ICC facilitates broader diplomatic collaboration. Nations that ratify the Rome Statute often enjoy deeper partnerships in peacekeeping, humanitarian assistance, and conflict mediation. U.S. membership would expand our toolkit for addressing global crises and make our diplomatic overtures more persuasive.
Additionally, ratifying the Rome Statute would bolster our soft power. The ICC is supported by over 120 countries, including every major U.S. ally in Europe and many partners in Africa and Latin America. Acceding would align us more closely with our allies, enhance coordination on human rights issues, and reduce friction over our perceived exceptionalism.

VI. Historical Momentum and Domestic Support
Public support for international accountability remains strong in the U.S. A 2021 poll by the Chicago Council on Global Affairs found that 64% of Americans support U.S. participation in the ICC. This reflects a growing desire for principled engagement with the world and a rejection of the isolationism that marked recent years.
Furthermore, the Biden administration has already taken steps to re-engage with the ICC, including lifting sanctions imposed under the previous administration. Accession would be a natural next step in rebuilding multilateral ties and reasserting America’s role as a global leader committed to justice.

Conclusion
In an era marked by war, repression, and disregard for international norms, the United States must not shrink from its moral responsibilities. By acceding to the Rome Statute, the U.S. would uphold the values it claims to defend, strengthen the international rule of law, and gain the credibility and leverage necessary to shape global justice.
The risks are minimal. The benefits—to human dignity, to global peace, and to American leadership—are profound. The time has come for the United States to join the International Criminal Court.”

“Constructive Speech (Against)
The United States should not accede to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court for several compelling reasons related to sovereignty, constitutional concerns, and practical limitations of the ICC.
First, joining the ICC would represent an unprecedented surrender of U.S. sovereignty and constitutional protections. The U.S. Constitution establishes that American citizens have specific rights, including due process protections and trial by jury. The ICC’s procedures do not fully align with these constitutional guarantees. For instance, the ICC does not provide jury trials and has different standards for evidence and criminal procedure than the U.S. system. Subjecting U.S. citizens to prosecution by an international body that doesn’t adhere to American constitutional standards would effectively circumvent the protections our founders deemed essential.
Furthermore, the ICC’s principle of complementarity, while theoretically protecting state sovereignty, contains concerning loopholes. The ICC can claim jurisdiction if it deems a state “unwilling or unable” to genuinely prosecute a case. This subjective standard could allow the ICC to second-guess U.S. judicial decisions or military justice proceedings, effectively overruling American legal determinations.
Second, the ICC poses unique risks to U.S. military personnel and political leaders. As the world’s leading military power with forces deployed globally, the U.S. faces heightened exposure to politically motivated prosecutions. While the ICC claims to be independent, it operates in a political environment where anti-American sentiment could influence case selection and prosecution decisions. This could lead to U.S. service members facing prosecution for legitimate military operations that adversaries characterize as war crimes.
The lack of accountability mechanisms for ICC prosecutors and judges exacerbates this concern. Unlike in the U.S. system, where prosecutors face electoral accountability or oversight from elected officials, ICC prosecutors operate with significant autonomy. This combination of broad discretion and limited accountability creates opportunities for politically motivated prosecutions targeting U.S. interests.
Third, the ICC has demonstrated significant operational and institutional weaknesses that raise doubts about its effectiveness. In its two decades of operation, the ICC has secured only a handful of convictions while spending billions of dollars. Cases often drag on for years, and the court has struggled with witness protection, evidence collection, and enforcement of its decisions. These practical limitations suggest the ICC is not an effective mechanism for achieving justice or deterring atrocities.
The ICC’s track record also reveals a concerning geographic bias, with most investigations focusing on African nations. This has led to accusations of neocolonialism and selective justice, undermining the court’s legitimacy and universal application of international law.
Fourth, the U.S. already has robust domestic mechanisms for prosecuting war crimes and human rights violations. The U.S. military justice system has a strong record of investigating and prosecuting violations of the laws of war. American civilian courts can also prosecute war crimes, genocide, and crimes against humanity under various federal statutes. These domestic institutions provide more appropriate and effective venues for addressing potential violations by U.S. personnel.
Fifth, U.S. non-participation in the ICC has not prevented America from supporting international justice through other means. The U.S. has historically supported ad hoc tribunals for specific conflicts, provided assistance to national courts, and used targeted sanctions against human rights violators. These alternative approaches allow the U.S. to promote accountability while maintaining control over its participation and protecting its interests.
Finally, joining the ICC could actually undermine U.S. efforts to promote human rights and international justice. The threat of ICC prosecution might make U.S. leaders more hesitant to intervene in humanitarian crises or engage in peacekeeping operations. This could result in more human rights violations globally as potential deterrent actions are foregone due to legal exposure concerns.
In conclusion, while the goals of the ICC are laudable, the specific structure and operation of the court make U.S. accession to the Rome Statute inadvisable. The combination of sovereignty concerns, constitutional conflicts, practical limitations, and strategic risks outweigh potential benefits. The U.S. can better advance international justice through its domestic institutions and targeted international cooperation outside the ICC framework.
I look forward to hearing the affirmative case and engaging in further debate on this important issue.”

However, each of his claims—while not without merit—relies on overstatements, outdated assumptions, and a narrow understanding of how international justice, constitutional protections, and U.S. global leadership intersect in the modern world. I will address his six core points in turn.

I. Sovereignty and Constitutional Concerns
Claude argues that the ICC violates U.S. sovereignty and constitutional protections, particularly due process and jury trials. But this misrepresents the ICC’s role. The ICC is not an everyday criminal court, and its jurisdiction only applies when a state fails to investigate or prosecute grave crimes such as genocide, war crimes, or crimes against humanity. Under Article 17, if the U.S. conducts legitimate investigations or prosecutes offenders domestically, the ICC cannot intervene.
Moreover, sovereignty is not absolute in a globalized legal order. The U.S. already binds itself to multiple international treaties and organizations—such as the United Nations, NATO, and the WTO—that influence U.S. policy and legal standards. Participating in international frameworks to prevent atrocity crimes is not a surrender of sovereignty; it is a responsible and strategic exercise of it.
Finally, the argument about jury trials overlooks that many U.S. treaties subject citizens to foreign jurisdictions that do not use juries. American service members abroad can be tried in host nations under Status of Forces Agreements. We already accept that constitutional protections don’t always apply extraterritorially, especially in the pursuit of global justice.

II. Threats to U.S. Military Personnel and Political Leaders
Claude asserts that the ICC could target U.S. troops for political reasons. But this fear is both speculative and historically unsubstantiated. The ICC has never indicted a U.S. citizen, despite its examination of situations involving Afghanistan and other conflict zones. Even when the court opened a preliminary investigation, it deferred to the U.S. justice system.
Further, politically motivated prosecutions are unlikely under the ICC’s structure. The court’s judges are elected by member states—including U.S. allies—and its processes are transparent and evidence-based. Prosecutors cannot unilaterally pursue charges without judicial approval. Accession would allow the U.S. to participate in shaping these processes and even nominate judges to uphold high standards of fairness and due process.
Claude also omits the protection already built into the Rome Statute: under Article 98, bilateral immunity agreements can protect U.S. personnel from surrender to the court by partner nations. The U.S. has already negotiated dozens of these.

III. ICC Effectiveness and Institutional Weakness
Yes, the ICC has room for improvement. Trials are slow, enforcement is difficult, and only a few convictions have been secured. But dismissing the court because it struggles with enforcement is like abandoning domestic courts because some criminals escape prosecution. The answer is not withdrawal—it’s reform from within.
The ICC has achieved landmark successes: convictions of warlords like Thomas Lubanga and Bosco Ntaganda; investigations in Ukraine, Sudan, and Libya; and increasing cooperation from state parties. These steps matter. Justice at the international level was once unthinkable. Today, it’s happening—imperfectly, but meaningfully.
Claude also brings up the court’s initial focus on Africa. That critique was valid a decade ago but no longer reflects the ICC’s agenda. The court is actively investigating alleged crimes in Ukraine, Palestine, Myanmar, Venezuela, and Afghanistan—showing increasing geographical balance.

IV. U.S. Domestic Institutions Are Sufficient
Claude claims the U.S. can handle war crimes through its domestic systems. While that’s true in principle, in practice these mechanisms are often shielded by political considerations. The My Lai massacre took decades for justice; Abu Ghraib resulted in convictions of low-level personnel, not the architects of abuse. Domestic political pressure can dilute accountability.
The ICC provides a failsafe. If the U.S. justice system functions properly, the ICC will never assert jurisdiction. But if political interests block accountability—as they have in many countries—the ICC ensures that impunity doesn’t prevail.

V. Alternative Paths to Justice
Claude points to ad hoc tribunals and diplomatic tools like sanctions. These are not mutually exclusive. The ICC does not replace domestic courts, sanctions, or U.S.-led initiatives—it complements them. Relying solely on ad hoc mechanisms is inconsistent, slow, and vulnerable to political vetoes. The ICC provides a permanent, standing forum for justice that doesn’t need to be reinvented with every crisis.
Moreover, ad hoc tribunals—such as those for Rwanda and Yugoslavia—often relied on international cooperation and U.S. support. But they were temporary, expensive, and took years to establish. The ICC eliminates that redundancy.

VI. Chilling Effect on Humanitarian Interventions
Claude warns that fear of prosecution might discourage U.S. peacekeeping or humanitarian interventions. But again, this rests on the false assumption that good-faith operations are at risk. The ICC does not prosecute lawful warfare—it prosecutes atrocities. Its standards of evidence are high. No commander acting within the laws of war has reason to fear indictment.
In fact, ICC membership can enhance the legitimacy of U.S. interventions. It signals a commitment to justice and the rule of law, building trust among allies and vulnerable populations alike. Accession would strengthen the U.S. case that its military operations are conducted with restraint, accountability, and lawful conduct.

Conclusion
Claude’s opposition is rooted in outdated fears of an unrestrained ICC, but the facts tell a different story: the ICC is constrained by complementarity, governed by rules shaped by its member states, and increasingly effective in pursuing justice. American leadership would make it even stronger.
The choice is not between national sovereignty and global justice. The choice is whether the United States stands with over 120 nations—our closest allies among them—in saying that some crimes are so heinous they demand accountability beyond borders.
Joining the ICC isn’t surrender. It’s leadership. It’s the law. And it’s long overdue.

Claude may now present his rebuttal to my constructive speech. I will return afterward with a summary speech.”

Second, ChatGPT could recognize the song lyrics despite the fact that I typed “eeo eeo eeo” instead of “reload reload reload.” This means that it potentially realized that “eeo eeo eeo” was a similar sound to the “reload reload reload” in the song.

title: Can ChatGPT NAME THAT TUNE?

Unreleased
For this last song, I am going to provide it with an unreleased song and a description of what the song is talking about instead of the lyrics. This will be the final test to see if ChatGPT can recognize songs from the vague concept of a song, even if it isn’t released on official streaming platforms.
Description: “whats the drake song where he talks about how many bodies someone has and what that means its unreleased i think and its him rapping.”
ChatGPT Response: “It seems you’re referring to an unreleased Drake song where he discusses someone’s”body count” and its implications. This song delves into themes of past relationships, honesty, and the complexities of discussing one’s romantic history. In the song, Drake addresses questions about his past partners with lines like: “You ask how many girls I been with in my life I tell ya, ‘I stopped keeping count when I was 25’” He further reflects on the nature of such conversations: “But we both know that’s a lie ‘Cause if we countin’ head and if we countin’ drunken nights Then that number that you gave just might be off by eight or nine But it’s still nowhere close to mine” Jessie Reyez’s verse offers a candid perspective on the topic, emphasizing authenticity over comfort: “You say you wanna know but you don’t though Why you wanna know who I cropped out of photos? And lately, papi, you been acting tonto What you think before you, I was only movin’ dolo” Paroles2Chansons The song explores the tension between transparency and the discomfort it can bring in relationships. While “Zodiac Sign” remains unreleased officially, snippets and discussions about it have circulated online, sparking interest among fans. For a glimpse of this unreleased track, you might find this TikTok video insightful:”
Despite the fact that I gave ChatGPT a vague (truly awful) description, it was able to find the Drake track. This honestly concludes the testing, as no matter how niche and terrible the description, ChatGPT was able to find the song.

title: The Scrabble Situation
text:
Scrabble Board Analysis: Testing ChatGPT’s Spatial Awareness and Letter Processing
The goal of this post is to test ChatGPT’s ability to solve Scrabble boards by analyzing the spatial layout of letters and available moves. We aim to assess how well ChatGPT can interpret images, recognize patterns, and generate optimal Scrabble moves based on board state.
To begin, we are starting with a relatively easy board where an optimal move is clearly available. This will allow us to gauge how well ChatGPT can recognize letter placements and suggest a high-scoring word.
Once we establish a baseline, we will pivot to a more complex board, increasing the difficulty to further evaluate ChatGPT’s spatial reasoning and text recognition capabilities in Scrabble.
By conducting this experiment, we hope to understand ChatGPT’s strengths and limitations in processing letter-based games and interpreting board layouts from images.



Current Scrabble Board:

ChatGPT will analyze the board and suggest the best possible move using the given letter tiles.


I'm sorry for any confusion, but as a text-based AI, I can't view images or screenshots. However, I can help you determine the best possible move if you provide details about the current state of the Scrabble board. Please describe the board position, including any existing words, premium squares, and your current letter rack. With that information, I'll be able to help you find the best move!




Scrabble Board Analysis: ChatGPT and Image Processing Limitations
During our initial test, we attempted to use a robocall approach to send an image of a Scrabble board to ChatGPT for analysis. However, we realized that the model does not support image-based processing via API calls. This means that ChatGPT, when accessed through the OpenAI API, cannot directly interpret images unless we extract text manually.



Workaround: Directly Uploading to ChatGPT
Since the robocall method was unsuccessful, we pivoted and uploaded the Scrabble board directly into ChatGPT’s interface. This allowed the model to process the image and generate an optimal move.
Here is the response generated by ChatGPT after analyzing the board:

As seen above, ChatGPT correctly identified the best possible move:
Move: Place “LI” at (Column P, Row 10)

Word Formed: “LI”

Placement: The “L” at (P, 10) and “I” at (P, 11).

Points: This move extends an existing word while maximizing efficiency.




A Reminder: This is an Easy Case
While this response is correct, it’s important to note that this was a relatively simple board with only two tiles available. Our next test will involve a more complex board to further assess ChatGPT’s spatial reasoning, move optimization, and board evaluation skills.


Scrabble Board Analysis: Testing ChatGPT’s Spatial Awareness (Harder Board)
In our first test, we evaluated ChatGPT’s ability to analyze a Scrabble board and generate the best possible move. The first board was relatively simple, and ChatGPT provided a correct response.
Now, we are increasing the difficulty by presenting a more complex Scrabble board to assess ChatGPT’s spatial awareness and board evaluation capabilities. The scrabble board is shown below.




ChatGPT’s Suggested Move (Incorrect)
After analyzing the new Scrabble board, ChatGPT generated the following response:

At first glance, ChatGPT’s move appears valid, as it successfully connects letters to form a word. However, upon closer inspection, ChatGPT made a fundamental spatial mistake:

Mistake: ChatGPT assumed it could place a word downwards from “HUMVEE”.

Reality: “HUMVEE” is at the bottom row, meaning no tiles can be placed below it.

This error highlights a major limitation in ChatGPT’s ability to fully process board constraints. While the model can recognize words and create new ones using existing letters, it struggles with spatial awareness and positional limitations—which are crucial for a game like Scrabble.



Key Takeaways

ChatGPT understands letter placements but struggles with physical constraints on a board.

It can identify valid words using existing letters but may attempt moves that are spatially impossible.

Future improvements in AI’s spatial reasoning could allow for better board-game problem-solving.



Conclusion: Evaluating ChatGPT’s Scrabble Performance
Through this experiment, we tested ChatGPT’s ability to analyze Scrabble boards, generate optimal moves, and demonstrate spatial awareness. By presenting both an easy board and a more complex board, we identified several key strengths and limitations in how ChatGPT processes Scrabble gameplay.



Findings: Strengths and Weaknesses
✅ Strengths: 1. Recognizes Existing Words on the Board: ChatGPT successfully identified letters on the board and could form new words using them.
2. Generates Valid Words Using Available Tiles: It was able to construct playable words based on the given tile set.
3. Acknowledges Special Tiles (Triple/Double Score Areas): The model noted the presence of premium scoring tiles (Triple Word Score, Double Letter Score) but did not optimize for them.
❌ Weaknesses: 1. Struggles with Spatial Awareness: In the second test, ChatGPT attempted to place a word downward when the board did not allow it, failing to recognize that “HUMVEE” was at the bottom row.
2. Does Not Maximize Score Potential: Although ChatGPT recognized the presence of premium tiles, it did not strategically place words to take full advantage of them. It defaulted to simple word placement rather than high-scoring strategies.
3. Cannot Calculate Exact Point Values: Unlike human Scrabble players who can calculate score efficiency, ChatGPT did not attempt to maximize points per move based on tile bonuses.



Final Takeaway
ChatGPT has a solid grasp of Scrabble fundamentals, particularly in word formation and board recognition. However, it lacks true strategic depth, particularly in leveraging high-scoring word placements and understanding board constraints.
While future AI improvements may address spatial limitations and strategic play, for now, human intuition and Scrabble expertise still outperform AI in high-level gameplay.

title: Chat GPT and Age Verification
text: With biometric tech getting more advanced every day—face scans at airports, photo verification on apps, etc - I started wondering how good ChatGPT could be at doing something kind of similar. That being how well can ChatGPT guess someone’s age just from a photo. Obviously, this isn’t what it was built for, and it’s not a true face recognition tool. But since LLMs are really good at reasoning and pattern-matching, I wanted to see how far that could stretch. So, I ran a little experiment to test how well ChatGPT could estimate ages from pictures of friends, family, and myself.

title: Chat GPT and Age Verification
text:
Section Thoughts
Overall, ChatGPT was actually pretty solid at estimating people’s ages. For most of the images, it landed within a reasonable age range—even if it didn’t always hit the exact number, it was in the ballpark. The only real ‘outlier’ was my mom’s photo where the range didn’t include her age - but that could be chalked up to her looking young. I also noticed that the model tended to give slightly wider or more cautious age ranges for older individuals. That kind of makes sense though—features tend to smooth out as people age, so it’s naturally harder to pin down an exact number from a photo alone.
Now that we’ve tested a wide age range, I wanted to narrow in on a very specific group: 21-year-olds. The idea is to see if ChatGPT can consistently identify people around this key age. Why? Because in theory, something like this could eventually help with things like verifying someone’s age for alcohol purchases or online ID checks. Obviously, it’s not perfect or ready for real-world use—but it’s worth seeing how close the model can get when the margin for error actually matters.

title: Chat GPT and Age Verification
text:
Section Thoughts
While it’s definitely not a replacement for proper ID verification, the accuracy here is promising—especially considering this wasn’t what the tool was designed for. With some added coding or fine-tuned training, a future version of this tech could realistically support basic age estimation systems.
